In propositional logic, if a statement P is true, then any statement of the form "P or Q" is also true, regardless of the truth value of Q. This is because the logical operator "or" only requires at least one of the statements to be true for the entire statement to be true.

In this case, let P be 'The report must have been accurate' and Q be 'The report must have been detailed'. If we know that P is true, then the statement "P or Q" (i.e., 'The report must have been accurate or detailed') is also true, regardless of whether Q is true or not.
